name: butanamide, n,n-dimethyl-
Reason: 1,3-Butanediamide has a basic melting point of around -10°C due to the presence of a rigid, symmetrical structure with a melting point-raising nitrogen atom. The two methyl groups can contribute to the melting point by approximately +20°C each, totaling +40°C. The carbonyl group can also participate in hydrogen bonding, which can increase the melting point by approximately +20°C. However, the exact impact of these functional groups on the melting point can be difficult to quantify without experimental data or detailed computational studies.
